Title: Clocks change tonight
Text: Donâ€™t forget to change your clocks this weekend.Â Daylight saving time begins at 2am on Sunday 27th March 2022, when clocks go forward one hour.Whatever happened to Poland abandoning time changes? Good question!Â  We reported back in Spring 2018 that Poland could become the first country in the EU to scrap time changes, however at that time it was considered that EU regulations, (not to mention common sense) would make this unlikely, in spite of cross party support.However in 2019, the European ParliamentÂ voted to end the twice-a-year (March and October) custom of time changes throughout the European Union, leaving member states the freedom to decide their standard time.The proposed change was scheduled for 2021, but disagreements at state level in the EU have put the plan on pause for the moment.Â  The national governments have yet to take a stance.The coronavirus pandemic (and arguably Brexit)Â  has pushed the issue of changing the time into the background.In Poland, consultations were carried out on changing the time â€“ 78 % were in favour of not changing clocks. Government data shows that most Poles prefer summer time.The final decision lies with the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament.Â  Â They will have to reach an agreement together for the proposal to take legal effect, and the council has not yet finalised its position.The Councilâ€™s final decision will be made on the basis of whatâ€™s called Qualified Majority Voting.Â  Which means that if 55% of countries representing at least 65% of the population of the EU want this to happen, even if the remaining countries vote against â€“ all countries have to go along with it.Previous Polish Debate In October 2017 a bill to abolish time changes unanimously passed its first reading in the Polish Parliament, having had rare cross party support. Â Supporters of the legislation argued that the twice-yearly time changes cause health problems,Â  damages the economy, disrupts businesses and does little to cut energy consumption.â€œThe time changes can lead to imbalances in the body-clock, leading to mood swings, trouble with sleeping, and an increased risk of heart attacks and road accidentsâ€Those against abolishing the time changes argue that being the only EU country not to change time in Spring and Autumn would cause massive problems for Poland;â€œThis will affect every person and every institution.Â You start with watches, smart phones and computers and end with complex industrial systems that control, for example, pipelines. The list of things that will need to be changed is endless.â€Abolishing the time change will also put Poland out of synchronisation with its EU neighbours, most importantlyÂ Germany, the countryâ€™s biggest trading partner.Poland introduced time changes during the interwar period, then in the years 1946-1949 and 1957-1964;Â Â it has been in force continuously since 1977.Â  Â EU Research â€˜Why we change the clocksâ€™ (2016)A Scot in KrakÃ³w. Title: 50 years of Australian-Polish Diplomatic Relations
Text:
On 20th February, Australia and Poland celebrated the 50th Anniversary of formal diplomatic relations since Poland regained her independence on 11 November 1918.The Polish and Australian Prime Ministers issued a joint statement to mark this anniversary, which concludes:-â€œFor 50 years, Australia and Poland have cooperated to build and enhance our strong bilateral relations. Today, we are proud of our friendship, confident in our shared interests and optimistic in the opportunities that lie ahead. â€ Brett Olaf, an Australian in KrakÃ³w, has researched Australian Polish links over the centuries.Beyond these 50 years, Australia and Poland have significant bonds that pre-date British settlement when Polish crew members sailed on a Dutch vessel in 1696. Poles have also settled in Australia since 1800s and the famous explorer, Sir PaweÅ‚ Edmund Strzelecki KCMG CB FRS FRGS DCL, explored much of Australiaâ€™s east coast, naming the highest peak, Mount Kosciusko, named for Polish hero, General Tadeusz KoÅ›ciuszko, and Gippsland after then then Governor of New South Wales (name given to Australiaâ€™s east coast at the time). Strzelecki himself having many landmarks named in his honour including Gippslandâ€™s Strzelecki Ranges in Australia and KrakÃ³wâ€™s Strzelecki Park adjacent KrakÃ³w Glowny.Photo: Strzelecki Park, KrakÃ³w, celebrates historical events and people including the Battle of Grunwald, a Berlin Wall fragment and Saint John Paul II. Credit: Brett OslerThere are also many KrakÃ³wians who made their way to the land Down Under including the Krakouers (Jewish KrakÃ³wians), whose descendants are renowned in Australian Rules football, as well as Aussies playing for KrakÃ³wian sporting teams such as Erin Phillips (Wisla Can Pack KrakÃ³w), Jacob Burn (Wisla KrakÃ³w), Shane Parker (Wanda KrakÃ³w), Michael Thwaite (Wisla KrakÃ³w).Notable KrakÃ³wians in Australia include former Sydney Lord Mayor, Leo Port MBE, actor Guido Lorraine, film producer and Krakow University graduate, Yoram Gross, who brought to life Blinky Bill: The Mischievous Koala and Dot and the Kangaroo, musician Leo Rosner, who â€˜delighted in playing Australian football theme songsâ€™ as recounted by his daughter, Anna Rosner Blay, and actress/comedian and author, Magda Szubanski, whose father hails from the Malopolska voivodeship and features in Babe, Happy Feet and plays her Kath and Kim character, Sharon Strzelecki, a sports obsessed fictional character.Photo: St Kilda FCâ€™s theme song, When The Saints Go Marching In, handwritten music by the City of Saintsâ€™ own Leo Rosner Credit: Danny Rosner Blay (Leoâ€™s grandson)Krakow is also the site of WWII plane crash involving two Australians, one now buried at Rakowicki Military Cemetery in KrakÃ³w, Squadron Leader John Liversidge, and the other, Flight Lieutenant Allan Hammet, ejecting safely and joining the Polish Home Army until the warâ€™s end. The plane crashed either side of the Vistula River with parts into the site of Galeria Kazimierz and others into Oskar Schindlerâ€™s Enamel Factory. A mural unveiled in 2018, a historical marker and Boulevard of Allied Airmen also mark this event with plans for a full-sized Liberator B-24 monument remain grounded for now. Many other Australians who were killed in action or as Prisoners of War are also buried at Rakowicki.Last Post Ceremony for Squadron Leader John LiversidgeÂ Photo: Plaque on the external wall of Oskar Schindlerâ€™s Enamel Factory commemorating those airmen lost in the crash of Squadron No. 178 Liberator B-24 KG-933 with part of the plane crashing into the factory on the night of 16 August 1944. Credit: Brett OslerPhoto: Burial site of RAAF Squadron Leader John Liversidge at KrakÃ³wâ€™s Rakowicki Military Cemetery whose Squadron No. 178 flight KG-933 was shot down over KrakÃ³w in 1944.
Credit: Brett OslerAustralian author, Thomas Keneally, wrote and won a Man Booker Prize for Schindlerâ€™s Ark which was famously adapted into Steven Spielbergâ€™s film, Schindlerâ€™s List. Krakowian musician, Leo Rosner, also made contributions to both of these. More recently, Australian Rules football has emerged in Krakow with AFL Krakow developing the game for men and women as well as AFL Europeâ€™s university contest, the Fitzpatrick Cup.Â  Krakowians interested in learning more about the game and joining in the action are invited to follow AFL Krakowâ€™s Facebook page.Image is the Australian Embassy of Warsaw / Polish Embassy of Canberra commissioned logo winner connecting an Australian kangaroo, a Polish eagleÂ and 50 into the logo.Australian Embassy Warsaw Australia in Poland, Czech Republic and Lithuania FacebookÂ Author: Brett Olaf, who hails from Australiaâ€™s Strzelecki Ranges.SHARE THIS ARTICLE USING THE BUTTONS BELOW

Makes about 20 to 24 pÄ…czkiTraditional Polish pÄ…czki â€“ yeast doughnuts filled with fruit preserves (rose jam) topped with icing or icing sugar.INGREDIENTS:2 cups whole milk, warmed to 110 degrees F
4Â½ teaspoons active dry yeast (2 packages)
Â¾ cup + 1 pinch granulated sugar, divided
5 to 6 cups all-purpose flour, divided
1 egg
4 egg yolks
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1Â¼ teaspoons salt
4 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted and cooled

Let stand for 5 to 10 minutes, or until it has become bubbly.2. Add 2 cups of flour to the mixture and stir with a wooden spoon until a smooth batter forms. Cover with plastic wrap and set in a warm spot for 30 minutes. The mixture should have risen and be very bubbly.3. In a medium bowl, whisk the egg and egg yolks until pale yellow and frothy, about 3 minutes. Add the sugar, vanilla extract and salt, and whisk until combined and smooth.4. Attach the dough hook to the mixer, add the egg mixture to the dough and mix on medium-low speed until mostly combined. Add the melted butter and mix to combine. Gradually add 3 more cups of flour to the mixture and continue to knead until a very soft dough comes together. If the dough doesnâ€™t hold its shape and springs back, cover with a damp towel and let rest for a few minutes and try again.7. Use a 3-inch biscuit cutter to cut out rounds of dough.
